questions.question: What is the empirical formula of FJI-H14?
What is the crystal system and space group of FJI-H14?
What temperature and pressure conditions were used for CO2 adsorption measurements in the study?
questions.answer: Measurements were performed at temperatures of 195, 273, 283, 288, 291, 293, 298, and 308 K and pressures up to 1 bar.

questions.question: How does the CO2 uptake of FJI-H14 at 298 K and 1 atm compare to that of Mg-MOF-74?
questions.answer: FJI-H14 has a CO2 uptake of 171 cm3 cm-3 at 298 K and 1 atm, which is lower than Mg-MOF-74's uptake of 176 cm3 g-1.

questions.question: What method was used to calculate the isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) for FJI-H14?
questions.answer: The isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) was calculated using both the Clausiusâ€“Clapeyron equation and the Virial fitting method.

questions.question: Is FJI-H14 stable in boiling water and acid/base environments?
questions.answer: Yes, FJI-H14 is very stable in boiling water and in both acid and base environments at pH = 2 to pH = 12 and at temperatures as high as 373 K.

questions.question: What is the role of open metal sites (OMS) and Lewis basic sites (LBS) in FJI-H14 for CO2 capture?
questions.answer: OMS and LBS in FJI-H14 synergistically capture CO2 molecules in the pores, improving the adsorption capacity more effectively than a single OMS or LBS.

questions.question: Can FJI-H14 be reused without losing its adsorption capacity?
questions.answer: Yes, FJI-H14 can be recycled without losing its adsorption capacity, maintaining 100% adsorption capacity even after five cycles.

questions.question: What makes FJI-H14 an ideal and practical adsorbent for post-combustion CO2 capture?
questions.answer: FJI-H14's high CO2 uptake and selectivity at ambient pressure, excellent chemical and thermal stability, good reusability, and the ability for large-scale production with low cost make it ideal for post-combustion CO2 capture.

questions.question: How does FJI-H14 catalyze the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates using simulated post-combustion flue gas?
questions.answer: FJI-H14 catalyzes the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates with high efficiency when using a mixed gas containing 0.15 atm CO2 and 0.85 atm N2 to simulate flue gas, showing higher catalytic activity compared to other catalysts.
